### | Description Swapfold is a single player origami puzzle/storyline-rpg mix top-down platformer game with a unique fundamental feature. Players must replicate actions on real world in order to find some solutions to puzzles. The main idea of the game to establishing a ground to show that games has potential as an environment to be a platform of education. On the completition of the game player should be able to learn few origami pieces through the method of associative learning. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/chapters.png)
Figure 1: Basic level origamis selected for each chapter
### | Story Our player is an apprentice mage who has to train portals. His supervisor gives him extraordinary tasks to complete. In order to understand how interdimensionality works you should be able to accurately represent and simulate them in simple dimensions. Idea comes from quartenions. So he/she starts to learn to play with simple tasks. However, during one of his tasks something goes wrong and a portal opens to demonic world of caridia. Now our characters needs to focus on his training to overcome this problem. ### | Base Gameplay Gameplay starts with a simple platformer game with moving around and exploring the world. With a simple mixed combat and puzzle feature for complex spells. Like a cookbook analogy in programming our character learns simple unitary modular folding techniques to create simple origami pieces, each of which associated with a power word, that could be used combine and casts spells ingame (ultima online / magicka / skyrim). This techniques progresss further on a skill tree. It is aimed that the skill tree also resembles what player learned in real life as well. On eah chapter player requires to create an origami piece. Writing a mark on number on each fold. At the end opening crafted orgami piece on 2D reveals a map on how to solve a puzzle in game. Each power word is associated with a folding technique. Player uses keyboard shortcuts to cast power words. Spells are usually combination of (usually 3 or 4) few power words. In rpg combat player must cast spells. A complex set of power words represent portals as well as origami pieces. Each power word is learned through a simple puzzle. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/skill_tree.png)
Figure 2: Fold and Power Word Asssociation on Skill Tree
### | Mechanics Basic game mechanics is a adjusted combination of two main mechanics. Those are moderate paced, environmentally interactive topdown rpg game play and puzzle solving. __Spell Word Combinations__ Each spell is combination of one or more power words. During rpg combat, player uses the combination of power words through _button combos_ to cast spell to overcome challenges. This combinations further helps player to solve puzzles through replicating origami pieces in real life. Example systems in real games (ultima online, skyrim, magicka) __Progressive Casting__ Casting a spell requires a small amount of time. Each cast process has three periods. Those are: _fizzle_, _success_, _excession_. With the analogy of cooking, _fizzle_ states represents a failing cast. If player ends casts too early, spell fizzles, simply fails without any effect. After the end of fizzle, _success_ period begins. During success, effect of spell increases exponantially until until excession period. The latest stage of the cast is _excession_ period. _Excession_ state is guaranteed failing cast and harms the player depending on the combination of spells. The harm is maximum at start and decreases parabolically up to half of maximum success effect. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/cast_graph.png)
Figure 3: Spell Effect Change In Relation To Cast Periods
On the combinations, different power words affect the cast time and proportions of the cast periods. Along with the mastery and usage frequency of the player. Through the mix of spell word combination and progressive casting, it is aimed to create create precision input button combos, fun to play but hard to master base combat mechanics of the game. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/cast_bar.png)
Figure 4: Periods of Cast Bar
__Real World Replication__ Player requires to solve a puzzle a to unlock, final chapter battles in game. A typical puzzle is again combination of power words, ingredients or keys to be used on certain sequence or places. This sequence is revealed through creating an origami piece through instructions explored in sub-chapters. On each fold player writes a power word on paper in real world. After completing and unfolding the origami piece, map for solving the puzzle is revealed. The sequence of instructions, and words are randomized to create unique map for each instance of the game. __Example Puzzle Chapter__ - Game consist of chapters each chapters corresponds an origami piece, and chapters consists of sub-chapters each of one corresponds to fold-technique. - During sub-chapter with different hints player learns origami by retrieves knowledge such as which fold-technique to be used, how many times and where. Player could replicate this information step to create origami piece. - On certain steps, player are given some additional power words (as runes) for portal keys. On this case, the given rune needs to be written on indicated area before applying the fold. - Completing the chapter, will result to complete the origami as well. However, to unlock next chapter, player requires to handle a boss fight. The boss fight room always resembles the unfolded paper of origami piece. On certain periods, boss stops and an area is indicated by color or light. On this time player should go to given area and cast the true power word. - If player had replicated given fold techniques in real life, unfolding the origami should reveal the true power words, in that player could use true power word to cast the portal. - Upon completing successful rpg boss fight with the combination of origami puzzle player defeats the boss and gains access to the new chapter. Along with learning an origami in real life. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/mapping.png)
Figure 5: Puzzle Solving Steps Depiction
__Puzzle Generation Steps__ 1. Description selected origami for the chapter as a composition of folding steps. 2. Decision on which steps to write a power rune on fold. 3. Writing of appropriate questline for each fold and rune to reveal map. 4. Design of boss fight mechanics and space that bears resemblance of unfolded origami. ### | Theory __Environmental Interactions__ As a general principle, it is aimed to increase the interaction with the environment for player. Environment is not only frozen entity to move and orient for next encounter but also, something to be aware of and act depending of the requirements of the place. Player should be able to change, alter or impact on the environment. At the same time strategicaly use it for personal progression. Example cases: - Frost based spells has multipliers to hit greater to wet enemies. - Player should avoid using fire spells on environment with dry woods to create fire. - Player should position themselves tactically to avoid impact boulder rolls, and even use this phenomenon to encounter with enemies. __Integrated Mini Games__ One of the problems that I have encountered in online games, that crafted objects costs lesser than material itself. Which is often wrong compared to the real world. The problem is gathering costs labor, however crafting does not, as a result since the material has variety of usage it worth more. To compete with this problem. It is aimed to set alternative progression mechanics such as crafting to be supported by engraved mini games to include and value them in labor. On further extreme, who whole complex game could be considered as a composition of mini games too. Example cases: - Progressive casting mechanism given above. - Lockpicking mechanism in Elder Scrolls series. - Hacking in Eve Online. __Internal Learning Mechanism__ The mechanic requirements to solve puzzles or progression is aimed to be engraved in-game as much as possible. Player should not progress with grind with frozen state of mind, but immerse him/herself in the game content and try to solve a problem to make a progress. Example casees: - Trolls could be killed by using fire spells learned through a book (Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, 2011) - On crafting, player must adjust the necessary conditions to create best possible variations of weapon. This information could be retrieved from someone, or something from ingame. To avoid duplication of the solution outside of the game. Given sources are randomized every game. On example, to forge a good sword, player should set the temperature to correct level. The level is described as a color of something (for instance a peach) ingame by someone or some text. Player should get a peach to compare colors to see correct level adjustment. __Technology and Skill Trees__ Another factor to establish an immersive environment is to push player to think and theorycraft the problem space created in-game. To create this environment, I consider, technology, and skill trees are good method to create complexity and considering people to think over variances and new possibilities to play and interract with the game. However, I belive skills trees should not shadow the players control over the character. Fundamental success should still be binded to player. __Environmental Interactions__ ### | Sub Systems __Time and Date__ A time system tracks day/night cycles and calendar to set events. To bind sense of time to certain events such as puzzles or social/unique events ingame that enhances to create more surrounding environment in parallelity with the idea of Gesamkunstwerk. __Inventory__ As a fundamental aspect of any role-playing game inventory system is aimed to include in Swapfold. To be able to progress on character, use of materials to create more powerful objects and increase environmental interaction. __Procedural Environment Generation__ Describing environment as modules and computationally bind this parts to describe seamlessly transitive places. The idea is to create relatively unique experience on each seed, as well as preventing the rote progression. - Example games using described system: Diablo series, Valheim, Don't Starve __Controlled Randomization__ - Map randomization: As a part of prodecural environment creation parts of the map is randomly customized - Puzzle randomization: To prevent same written guide to pass the game without playing it. The fold hints are given randomly to form a unique form for each puzzle instance. ### | References __Visual References__ 1. _Figure 1._ Basic level origamis selected for each chapter. _data.title: Why I want to make games?

toc.text: Game as Total Work of Art

children.value: Hello world, my name is Kutay Coşkuner, and this is my game design portfolio.

This work has composed of four chapters. While the first three chapters contain my work on game design, in this chapter that I added later, I tried to list the reasons why I wanted to make a game. If you are not willing to read a relatively long essay, you can skip this section.
Otherwise, thank you for your time.
Game as Total Work of Art

I have great affection for analyzing and creating things. Since the childhood I found myself in virtual dimensions of computer games as a vast field of exploration. I am amazed by how people combined designed systems and worlds using mathematics and art to resemble either life itself or non-existent world out of their imaginations.

During my master education I have meet with various concepts and persons that contributed me a lot. One of these concepts were Gesamtkunstwerk, a total work of art. Concept coined by Richard Wagner to describe what he aimed to create rather than aesthetic experience, a new dimension that could surround the experiencing person and make them to feel something immersive and new. I was very excited by this concept because it clearly articulated the idea that imagination and artistic production could offer something more than an aesthetic experience that I was enthusiastic about.

Although Wagner aimed to create this through the medium of opera, today many considers cinema as the new form of total work of art. Cinema is powerful enough for us to feel and experience completely new out of this world. I have no objection to the opinion that cinema. However when I first heard about the concept, first thing come to my mind was Ultima Online. An overengineered mmorpg by Richard Garriott was able to create this dimension for me, with a further point that cinema could not reach in that time, the interaction. Cinema could make people cry, to experience something new but they are rarely include viewer as participant to their world (There are some discrete limited examples such as Black Mirror). In my experience, computer games and architecture are proven to be able to carry the potential of Gesamkunstwerk. They are capable to create, through an extended level of interaction, one could experinnce new world and beyond, one could interact with it though decisions and characteristic features. However due the required complexity of these works, we rarely encounter such games. As a result, I have always had the desire to pass on my experience to others as if I had seen a new color. In order to show people that another life and a better world is possible, the concept of Gesamtkunstwerk offers the power to express this and computer games offer a method.

Secondly, in 2016 I met with a youtube channel Primer by Justin Helps.  He is simulating famous theories through animation, statistics, and computer science. On the one hand, I think the way he presents his thought experiments with statistically based proofs, and on the other hand, the way he expresses it in a clear and very understandable way, and the way he presents it with effort and visualization, I think creates extraordinary works. What the Primer videos made me realize is that they provide an extraordinary platform for data generation, experimentation, and scientific inference in sociology, economic and public science in my analysis of online gaming experiences.

To illustrate this, online games of a certain size and complexity have economies that are like small-scale simulations of real life. By analyzing the ledgers in these economies and analyzing the data, we can clearly observe behavioral patterns that parallel those in the real world. Can people's behavior change from cooperative to cooperative in crisis situations (See Corrupted Blood Incident - World of Warcraft) How does human behavior change with inflation (Gold Pruning Events - Ultima Online/ World of Warcraft) Can we channel the time people spend having fun into producing functional scientific output (See Project Discovery - Eve online). Some of the conclusions that I find functional in life are that money is not a measure of value but a representation mechanism, and that labor is the real value. The system of risk and reward and the balance of supply and demand advocated by classical economics does not work linearly. To summerize, I think that game platforms can exist as potential and powerful platforms for scientific experimentation and production other than private beneficial purposes, but that this potential is rarely used, although there are examples. As a game designer, I think this potential should be assessed.

I hesitate to add the third aspect, because previous attempts with similar premises, such as television and youtube, have not worked out so well, but I will add it anyway because it is my peak goal. I think games as an educational platform can contribute to social development to form a better society and environment.

In nature, when we look at the concept of game, we see that it works as a simulation that gives the living being the abilities that prepare it for life. I think a similar template can be applied to counter the current notion of games as a market commodity where entertainment is sold. I think that games have the potential to be not only a means of transmitting functional knowledge, as in the case of survival in nature, but also educational platforms that offer causality to create a more just society, to become bettere over nature and sustainable environment. To extend this idea, I would like to example from architecture (another Gesamkunstwerk) through famous illustration of Panopticon by Michael Foucault.

Foucault has seen architecture as inevitably political action. In other words, architecture changes society through subtle political statements through organizing, controlling, and defining the space. Foucault uses a blatant instance of the Panopticon to concrete his argument. Panopticon is a prison design produced as an idea experiment. The biggest problem of surveillance mechanisms is the numerical proportional difference between the actors. In other words, it is not possible to have a guard watch each prisoner, and it is not efficient either. Panopticon is a cylindrical prison, where in the middle, stands a watchtower for the guards, and prisoners in its perimeters. The overhead light prevents the prisoners from seeing the guards, while the guards are at any angle could observe each individual prisoners. Prisoners cannot know if they are being watched, as they cannot see the guards. Even if the guards are few in number, the prisoners have to act on the assumption that they are being watched. At the theoretical level, the problem is solved only with the spatial organization, namely architecture. Foucault has used it to express how architecture can shape human behavior through an extreme example like Panopticon. Although Foucault's example is negative and pessimistic, this potential is not only there to establish autocratic control, but to convey the causality phenomena that will make it possible to produce more free, just and sustainable environment for all. Indeed, as a more positive example, psychologist and educator Loris Malaguzzi referred to the place as the "third teacher" on the educational buildings, as it is referred to architecture could play a role to establish values such as equality, justice, freedom for all living beings and nature.

Beyond that, I think I have experimented with the idea that games can be educational platforms. To exemplify at the individual level, I got my thoughts on economics and sociology from my abstracted simulation experiences in games. I have seen how people act in crisis situations. Games taught me the difference between fact and image, and awareness of the ideas such as rhetoric over logic
, on social experiences. I learned the second language English through games, and the idea of the dichotomous relationship between chaos and order
, which later contributed to my master thesis in architecture. Regardless of the right or wrong of my thoughts, I think that games had a great impact on the formation of my intellectual identity.

To summarize, I believe that games have the potential to be a complete work of art, a platform for experimentation, as well as a platform for education and social development, but this potentials are rare except some subtle extraordinary cases. Just like the value that I have gained from games, I think that by creating works with this potential, I can add new dimensions to the perception of the game and create works that could add value to humanity that has not only have artistic and scientific value but also something that could allows us to create a better, self-sustainable, and fair society.
This is the end of my game design portfolio.
Thank you for your time and attention. :)
. 2016. I believe this is very good example of subtle messages on sustainability and supporting local communities.
. 1994-2011. Schools of magic, illusion and alteration. Ability to progress by the skill speechcraft is genuinely realistic representation.
Electronic Arts, Origin Systems, Mythic Entertainment.
. 1997. Each character is based on in between position of chaos, order through karma mechanism.
Brown, Mark. How Video Game Economies are Designed.
Callert, Glen. How Stardew Valley Was Made by Only One Person.
Coşkuner, Kutay. The Void of Fictionalized Perception: Affections of Media and Cinema with regard to Delusional Demand on the Formation of Built Environment in Turkey.
In Arch513, Middle East Technical University
Holert, Tom. “Politik des Lernens, Politik des Raums. Der Bildungsschock der 1960er und 1970er Jahre”.
In Bildungsschock: Lernen, Politik Und Architektur in Den 1960er Und 1970er Jahren
In Berleant, A. and Carlson, A. eds. The Aesthetics of Human Environment

To illustrate this, online games of a certain size and complexity have economies that are like small-scale simulations of real life. By analyzing the ledgers in these economies and analyzing the data, we can clearly observe behavioral patterns that parallel those in the real world. Can people's behavior change from cooperative to cooperative in crisis situations (See Corrupted Blood Incident - World of Warcraft) How does human behavior change with inflation (Gold Pruning Events - Ultima Online/ World of Warcraft) Can we channel the time people spend having fun into producing functional scientific output (See Project Discovery - Eve online). Some of the conclusions that I find functional in life are that money is not a measure of value but a representation mechanism, and that labor is the real value. The system of risk and reward and the balance of supply and demand advocated by classical economics does not work linearly. To summerize, I think that game platforms can exist as potential and powerful platforms for scientific experimentation and production other than private beneficial purposes, but that this potential is rarely used, although there are examples. As a game designer, I think this potential should be assessed.

## Platform for Education
I hesitate to add the third aspect, because previous attempts with similar premises, such as television and youtube, have not worked out so well, but I will add it anyway because it is my peak goal. I think games as an educational platform can contribute to social development to form a better society and environment. 

In nature, when we look at the concept of game, we see that it works as a simulation that gives the living being the abilities that prepare it for life. I think a similar template can be applied to counter the current notion of games as a market commodity where entertainment is sold. I think that games have the potential to be not only a means of transmitting functional knowledge, as in the case of survival in nature, but also educational platforms that offer causality to create a more just society, to become bettere over nature and sustainable environment. To extend this idea, I would like to example from architecture (another Gesamkunstwerk) through famous illustration of Panopticon by Michael Foucault. 

Foucault has seen architecture as inevitably political action. In other words, architecture changes society through subtle political statements through organizing, controlling, and defining the space. Foucault uses a blatant instance of the Panopticon to concrete his argument. Panopticon is a prison design produced as an idea experiment. The biggest problem of surveillance mechanisms is the numerical proportional difference between the actors. In other words, it is not possible to have a guard watch each prisoner, and it is not efficient either. Panopticon is a cylindrical prison, where in the middle, stands a watchtower for the guards, and prisoners in its perimeters. The overhead light prevents the prisoners from seeing the guards, while the guards are at any angle could observe each individual prisoners. Prisoners cannot know if they are being watched, as they cannot see the guards. Even if the guards are few in number, the prisoners have to act on the assumption that they are being watched. At the theoretical level, the problem is solved only with the spatial organization, namely architecture. Foucault has used it to express how architecture can shape human behavior through an extreme example like Panopticon. Although Foucault's example is negative and pessimistic, this potential is not only there to establish autocratic control, but to convey the causality phenomena that will make it possible to produce more free, just and sustainable environment for all. Indeed, as a more positive example, psychologist and educator Loris Malaguzzi referred to the place as the "third teacher" on the educational buildings, as it is referred to architecture could play a role to establish values such as equality, justice, freedom for all living beings and nature. <sup>1</sup>

Beyond that, I think I have experimented with the idea that games can be educational platforms. To exemplify at the individual level, I got my thoughts on economics and sociology from my abstracted simulation experiences in games. I have seen how people act in crisis situations. Games taught me the difference between fact and image, and awareness of the ideas such as rhetoric over logic <sup>2</sup>, on social experiences. I learned the second language English through games, and the idea of the dichotomous relationship between chaos and order <sup>3</sup>, which later contributed to my master thesis in architecture. Regardless of the right or wrong of my thoughts, I think that games had a great impact on the formation of my intellectual identity.

To summarize, I believe that games have the potential to be a complete work of art, a platform for experimentation, as well as a platform for education and social development, but this potentials are rare except some subtle extraordinary cases. Just like the value that I have gained from games, I think that by creating works with this potential, I can add new dimensions to the perception of the game and create works that could add value to humanity that has not only have artistic and scientific value but also something that could allows us to create a better, self-sustainable, and fair society.

This is the end of my game design portfolio.   
Thank you for your time and attention. :)

# Notes
1. Barone, Eric. pseudonym: ConcernedApe. _Stardew Valley_. 2016. I believe this is very good example of subtle messages on sustainability and supporting local communities.

2. Bethesda Softworks. _Elder Scrolls Series_. 1994-2011. Schools of magic, illusion and alteration. Ability to progress by the skill speechcraft is genuinely realistic representation.

3. Electronic Arts, Origin Systems, Mythic Entertainment. _Ultima Online_. 1997. Each character is based on in between position of chaos, order through karma mechanism.

# References
1. "Corrupted Blood Incident". _In Wikipedia_. 2023. Accessed (28 Mar 2023) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corrupted_Blood_incident

2. "Panopticon". _In Wikipedia_. 2023. Accessed (28 Mar 2023) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panopticon

3. "Project Discovery". _In Eve Online_ [Website]. 2020. Accessed (28 Mar 2023) https://www.eveonline.com/discovery

4. Brown, Mark. How Video Game Economies are Designed. _Game Maker's Toolkit, Youtube_ [Video File]. 2022. Accessed (28 Mar 2023) https://youtu.be/Zrf1cou_yVo

5. Callert, Glen. How Stardew Valley Was Made by Only One Person. _ThatGuyGlen, Youtube_ [Video File]. 2020. Accessed (28 Mar 2023) https://youtu.be/4-k6j9g5Hzk

6. Coşkuner, Kutay. The Void of Fictionalized Perception: Affections of Media and Cinema with regard to Delusional Demand on the Formation of Built Environment in Turkey. _In Arch513, Middle East Technical University_. 2019. 

7. Helps, Justin. Primer Learning. _In Youtube_ [Website]. 2018. Accessed (28 Mar 2023)  https://www.youtube.com/@PrimerBlobs/featured

8. Holert, Tom. “Politik des Lernens, Politik des Raums. Der Bildungsschock der 1960er und 1970er Jahre”. _In Bildungsschock: Lernen, Politik Und Architektur in Den 1960er Und 1970er Jahren_. Berlin: De Gruyter. 2020: 14-66.

_data.text:
## Prapositionen II: Ortangaben | Am, Im, Um # Ortsangaben In German, the preposition use with directions are dependent on two factors. Those are: 1. The question: Woher? (from where), Wo? (where). and Wohin? (to where) 2. Type of Place: enclosed space, city/country, people etc. | | Woher? ?->i (Dativ) | Wo? x (Dat) | Wohin? i->? (Akk) | | :--------- | :---------- | :-- | :-- | | **Stadt/Land** | aus | in | nach | **Menschen** | von | bei | zu | **Enclosed Space** | aus / von | in | zu / in | **Haus** | von zu | zu | nach - Examples - Stadt/ Land - Woher? Ich komme **aus** der Türkei. - Wo? Jetzt bin ich **in** Berlin. - Wohin? Ich fahre **nach** Kassel. - Menschen - Woher? Ich komme **aus** Jen. - Wo? Ich bin **bei** Kenny. - Wohin? Ich fahre **zu** Fabian. - Eingeschlossener Raum (Enclosed Space / Space with limits) - Woher? Ich komme **von** der Uni. - Wo? Ich esse **in** der Mensa. - Wohin? Ich gehe zum Laufen **in** den Park. - Haus - Woher? Ich komme von zu Hause. - Wo? Ich bin zu Hause. - Wohin? Er ist auf dem Weg nach Hause. # Um, Im, Am - To indicate days of the week we use **am**: - am Montag, am Dienstag, am Vormittag, am Nachmittag, am Morgen - For seasons we use: **im**: - im Frühling, im Sommer, im Winter, im Herbst - To talk about a time in precision we use **um**: - um 19 Uhr - um 12 Uhr - um 15 Uhr 30 - um Mitternacht - Verb conjugation - an + dem = **am** - in + dem = **im** ## Zeitform II: Perfekt One of the fundamental aspects language is speaking about the past. The most basic grammatik time form (das Tempus) of past (die Vergangenheit) is **Perfekt**. In order to be able to create sentences in Perfekt. One needs to have various basic knowledge. 1. **Understanding of verb positioning** in German sentences. Since perfekt requires two verbs in one sentence. 2. **Partizip II** A special type of verb conjugation that is used in perfect and passiv sentences. | Examples | Präsens | Perfekt | | :-- | :-- | :-- | | **sein regular** | Ich fahre nach Berlin. | Ich bin nach Berlin gefahren. | **sein irregular** | Ich gehe nach Hause. | Ich bin nach Hause gegangen. | **haben regular** | Ich lese das Buch. | Ich habe das Buch gelesen. | **haben irregular** | Ich esse zu viel. | Ich habe zu viel gegessen. Perfect sentences in German language uses passing conjugation of auxiliary verb (sein or haben). Which form is going to be used is dependent on the verb. 90% of the words uses "haben" while relocation indicating verbs such as gehen, fahren, laufen uses "sein". There are also some exceptions. Second part is the Partizip II version of the main verb. In Partizip II there are regular and irregular versions. Often needs to be learned by heart. **Conjugating Partizip II** Partizip II is also known as the past partipciple formed by adding prefix "ge-", and suffix "-t" or "-et" to the verb stem. It used in various ways. | Infinitiv | Stamm | Partizip II | Regular?| | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | | machen | mach | **ge**mach**t** | ja | spielen | spiel | **ge**spiel**t** | ja | lernen | lern | **ge**lern**t** | ja | sein | sei | gewesen | nein | haben | hab | gehabt | nein - **To form the Perfekt tense** - ex. Gestern habe ich eine E-Mail **geschrieben.** - To form the passive voice - Das Haus wurde **gebaut.** - A an adjective - ex. Ein **gekochtes** Ei # Beispiele im Perfekt 1. Ich lerne Deutsch - Ich habe Deutsch gelernt. (regular) 2. Er trinkt Kaffee. - Er hat Kaffee getrunken. (irregular) 3. Wir sprechen jeden Tag Deutsch. - Wir haben jeden Tag Deutsch gesprochen. (irregular) 4. Sie arbeitet in einer Firma. - Sie hat in einer Frima gearbeitet. (regular) 5. Ich esse gerne Pizza. - Ich habe gerne Pizza gegessen. (irregular) 6. Er liest ein Buch. - Er hat ein Buch gelesen. (irregular) 7. Wir fahren Morgen in den Urlaub. - Wir sind in den Urlaub gefahren. (Morgen passt hier kontextuell nicht.) (irregular) 8. Sie schreibt einen Brief. - Sie hat einen Brief geschrieben. (irregular) 9. Ich höre gerne Musik. - Ich habe gerne Musik gehört. (regular) 10. Er besucht seine Großeltern. - Er hat seine Großeltern besucht. (irregular) # Verbformen In Deutsch | | Description | Formulation | Example | | :--------- | :---------- | :-- | :-- | | Infinitiv | basic form of the verb | -en | machen, erhalten. | Partizip I | used to modify verbs as adjektives | -end + .. | sprechend, laufend | Partizip II | used for perfekt, pqm and passiv | ge- v -t (has exceptions) | gesagt, gemacht | Indikativ | contextual form: to tell facts | -en | Wir unternehmen einen Ausflug | Konjunktiv I | indirect/reported speech | -e (has exceptions) | Er unternehme einen Ausflug. | Konjunktiv II | to tell irreal/ hypothetical situations | wäre | Wäre es nicht schön, wenn wir einen Ausflug unternähmen? | Imperativ | use this mode for commands | used stem | Nimm das! source: https://german.stackexchange.com/questions/43196/what-are-indikativ-konjunktiv-i-konjunktiv-ii-of-any-verb-like-unternehmen ## Adjektiv Deklination In German Language, adjectives that used before the noun receives a declension. This depends on three factors: - gender of the noun's article (der/die/das) - case (nom/akk/dat/gen) - the type of artikel (das/ein). | | Maskulinum | Femininum | Neutrum | Plural | |:-- |:-- |:-- |:-- | :-- | | nominativ | de**r** rot*e* Mantel
ein rot**er** Mantel | die rot**e** Jacke
eine rot**e** Jacke | da**s** rot**e** Kleid
ein rot**es** Kleid | die rot**en** Mäntel

Ich sehe ein**en** schön**en** Hund. (akk. m. ua.) 2. Sie hat ein**e** groß**e** Wohnung. (Akkusativ femininum) 3. Das ist ein nett**es** Mädchen. (Nominativ neutrum) 4. Case refers to the grammatical category of a noun, pronoun, or adjective that reflects its syntactic and semantic role in a sentence.

There are four cases in German grammar. Table below is to represent rough functions of these cases in the sentence and all of them color coded. While the nominative case is part of former chapters. In here, akkusativ and dativ cases will be focused.
There are four situations to identify accusative object in German.
Direct object: In most basic example, accusative case refers to the direct object in sentence. Or in other words what is being "verbed".
In this example verb is "gebe" give what is given: the book
This condition could be identified by the questions in the sentence
Accusative prepositions: Some prepositions in German always require accusative case. Those prepositions are:
The direct object in the accusative case, governed by the preposition "gegen."
Accusative personal pronouns: There are accusative version of pronouns that indicates the case in sentence. Those needs to be learned by heart.
Mich is personal pronoun accusative version of nominative ich.
Indefinite pronouns: Indefinite pronouns like someone (jemand) or something (etwas) are always in accusative case.
Something is indefinite pronoun always in accusative.
Accusative object in German sentences changes the definite or indefinite article of the object. The only difference between nominativ and accusative case occurs on masculine articles.

Dative case in german refers to indirect object in sentence. The dative object is something affected by the action occured in sentence. It could be the noun that receives something in accusative case. The question to be asked to sentence to dative case is "Was?(what)".

Indirect object: The Dative case is used for the indirect object of a sentence. To determine the indirect object, ask "to/for whom" or "to/for what" the verb is acting upon. The indirect object usually comes before the direct object in the sentence.
In this example the object book is given to who?

## Satzstruktur I: Hauptsatz und Nebensatz Word order and subordinate clauses: German language has a strict positioning rule about the verbs. Those are: - **Hauptsatz:** (main clauses) Sentences that stands alone as a whole. The verb stand always in second position. - A single sentence may contain two or more verbs. The positioning may vary dependent on case, however in most situations like **modals verbs** auxiliary verb comes to second position while main verb goes to the end of the sentence. - ex. **Modalverb:** Ich kann mir vorstellen. - ex. **Perfekt:** Ich habe gestern gearbeitet. - **Attention:** Second position does not mean second word. First position might belong to a clause. - ex. Deutsche Grammatikbücher sind sehr teuer. - **Haupsatz Konnektoren:** There are three basic connectors in German language to bind Hauptsatz. Those are, **und (and)**, **oder (or)**, and **aber (or)**. Those connectors. In Grammatical sense, these connectors refers to a new sentence beginnings. Could be regarded as dot. - ex. Ich gehe ins Kino, und meine Freunde kommen mit. - ex. Entweder gehen wir ins Kino, oder wir bleiben zu Hause. - ex. Ich möchte ins Kino gehen, aber ich habe kein Geld. - **Nebensatz:** (subordinate clauses) Usually gives additional information about the main sentence. Could indicate reason, result etc. Subordinate clauses are there to create more complex sentences. And binded the main sentence with a specific connector Could be skipped for now. Yet there it might be helpful to see an example. - ex. Ich trinke Tee, weil ich Halsschmerzen habe. ## Modalverben In German, modal verbs are a type of auxiliary verb that express modalities such as ability, possibility, permission, necessity, and obligation. There are 6 modal verbs in German. Those are: | Modalverb | Trans | Example | | :--------- | :---------- | :-- | | **können** | to be able to / can | ich kann schwimmen. | **müssen** | must / have to | er muss seine Aufgaben erledigen. | **sollen** | should / should be supposed to | wir sollten nach Reykjavik gehen. | **dürfen** | may / be allowed to | Sie dürfen hier nicht rauchen. | **wollen** | want to | Ihr wolltet zu uns kommen. | **möchten** | would like to | Sie will Tennis spielen. In order to use modalverbs correctly in Grammar. One needs to be aware of couple of things. 1. Verb position structure: In most basic German sentence 2. Declination of the modal verb according to subject. ## Kasus II: Akkusativ und Dativ # Accusative case **What is case** Case refers to the grammatical category of a noun, pronoun, or adjective that reflects its syntactic and semantic role in a sentence. There are four cases in German grammar. Table below is to represent rough functions of these cases in the sentence and all of them color coded. While the nominative case is part of former chapters. In here, akkusativ and dativ cases will be focused. | Case | Function | Examle | |:-- |:-- |:-- | | Nominativ | Subject of verb | Ich gebe. | Akkusativ | Direct object | Ich gebe das Grammatikbuch. | Dativ | Indirect object | Ich gebe meinem Vater das Grammatikbuch. | Genitiv | Possession indicative | Ich gebe meinem Vater das Grammatikbuch der deutschen Sprache. **How to identify accusative case?** There are four situations to identify accusative object in German. 1. Direct object: In most basic example, accusative case refers to the direct object in sentence. Or in other words what is being "verbed". | | | | :---------: | :---------------------: | | **Example** | Ich gebe das Buch. | **Explanation** | In this example verb is "gebe" give what is given: the book
This condition could be identified by the questions in the sentence **what?** 2. Accusative prepositions: Some prepositions in German always require accusative case. Those prepositions are: _durch_, _für_, _gegen_, _ohne_, _um_ and _entlang_. | | | | :---------: | :---------------------: | | **Example** | Ich fahre *gegen* die Wand. | **Translation** | I drive against the wall. | **Explanation** | The direct object in the accusative case, governed by the preposition "gegen." 3. Accusative personal pronouns: There are accusative version of pronouns that indicates the case in sentence. Those needs to be learned by heart. | Nominativ | Akkusativ | Dativ | :-- | :-- | :-- | | ich | mich | mir | du | dich | dir | er | ihn | ihm | sie | sie | ihr | es | es | ihm | wir | uns | uns | ihr | euch | euch | sie | sie | ihnen | Sie | Sie | Ihnen | | | | :---------: | :---------------------: | | **Example** | Er sieht mich. | **Translation** | He sees me. | **Explanation** | Mich is personal pronoun accusative version of nominative ich. 4. Indefinite pronouns: Indefinite pronouns like someone (jemand) or something (etwas) are always in accusative case. | | | | :---------: | :---------------------: | | **Example** | Ich suche etwas. | **Translation** | I am looking for something. | **Explanation** | Something is indefinite pronoun always in accusative. **Grammatical changes of accusative case** Accusative object in German sentences changes the definite or indefinite article of the object. The only difference between nominativ and accusative case occurs on masculine articles. | | Masculine | Feminine | Neuter | Plural | | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | | Nominativ | der | die | das | die | | Akkusativ | den | die | das | die | # Dativ Case Dative case in german refers to indirect object in sentence. The dative object is something affected by the action occured in sentence. It could be the noun that receives something in accusative case. The question to be asked to sentence to dative case is "Was?(what)". **How to identify dative case?** 1. Indirect object: The Dative case is used for the indirect object of a sentence. To determine the indirect object, ask "to/for whom" or "to/for what" the verb is acting upon. The indirect object usually comes before the direct object in the sentence. | | | | :---------: | :---------------------: | | **Example** | Ich gebe meinem Vater das Buch. | **Explanation** | In this example the object book is given to who?
This condition could be identified by the questions in the sentence **whom?** 2. Dative prepositions: Some prepositions always require the Dative case. These include "aus" (out of), "bei" (at), "mit" (with), "nach" (after), "seit" (since), "von" (from), "zu" (to), and "gegenüber" (opposite). | | | | :---------: | :---------------------: | | **Example** | Ich gehe *mit* meinem Freund ins Kino. | **Explanation** | "Meinem Freund" is the indirect object in the dative case, governed by the preposition "mit". 3. Indirect object pronouns: Pronouns that represent the indirect object in a sentence are in the Dative case. | Nominativ | Akkusativ | Dativ | :-- | :-- | :-- | | ich | mich | mir | du | dich | dir | er | ihn | ihm | sie | sie | ihr | es | es | ihm | wir | uns | uns | ihr | euch | euch | sie | sie | ihnen | Sie | Sie | Ihnen | | | | :---------: | :---------------------: | | **Example** | Sie schickt mir eine E-Mail. | **Explanation** | "Mir" ist dative form of "ich" and represents indirect object in the sentence. **Grammatical changes of dative case** Dative object in German sentences changes the definite or indefinite article of the object. | | Masculine | Feminine | Neuter | Plural | | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | | Nominativ | der | die | das | die | | Akkusativ | den | die | das | die | | Dativ | dem | der | dem | den |

The most common are: Some of the prepositions could be either dativ or akkusativ while some are found only on one case. For the prepositions that could both take akkusativ and dativ case, the case is determined through asking questions **wo? wohin? or woher?** - Wo? und Woher? is dativ case. - Wohin? is akkusativ case. | Präp | Description | Example | Case | | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | | an | near, next | Das Bild hängt an der Wand. | A/D | auf | on | Das buch liegt auf dem Tisch. | A/D | hinter | behind | Ich gehe hinter dem Auto. | A/D | in | in | Ich bin in der Schule. | A/D | neben | next | Das Café liegt neben dem Park. | A/D | über | above, over | Das Flugzeug fliegt über den Wolken. | A/D | unter | under | Die Katze liegt unter dem Tisch. | A/D | vor | Front | Ich stehe vor dem Haus. | A/D | zwischen | in between | Der Fluss fließt zwischen den beiden Bergen. | A/D | aus | from | ich komme aus der Türkei. | D | zu | to | Ich gehe zu meinem Freund nach Hause. | D | von .. nach .. | from.. to.. | Ich reise von Berlin nach München mit dem Zug. | D | gegenüber | opposite | Das Restaurant ist gegenüber dem Bahnhof. | D | um/herum | around | Wir sund um die Welt gereist. | A | durch | through | Ich gehe jeden Tag durch den Park. | A | gegen | against | Die Mannschaft spielt gegen die beste Mannschaft. | A

## Partizip I als Adjektiv Partizip I (also known as "present participle" or "gerund") in German is a non-finite verb form that ends in "-end", "-ierend", or "-end" depending on the verb. It is formed by adding the suffix "-end" or "-ierend" to the verb stem, and can function as an adjective, a noun or a verb. As an adjective, Partizip I describes an **ongoing action**, state or condition. It can be used to describe a person, an object or a situation. As partizip I converts verb to an adjektiv it is also followed by adjective declination: lauf**end**e Nase (running nose) arbeit**ende**r Mensch (working person) schwing**end**e Hängematte (swinging hammock) Nur der _Denk**end**e_ erlebt sein Leben, am Gedankenlosen zieht es vorbei. (Only the thinking one experiences the life, it passes by the thoughtless one.) -Marie von Ebner-Eschenbach, 1893 ## Zeitform IV: Futur I In German, the future tense is usually formed using the auxiliary verb **werden** (to become) followed by the infinitive form of the main verb. The use case of Futur I is to describe **predictions**, **assumptions** or **planned** tasks in the future. For regular tasks Präsens is often used. To form the future tense, you need to use the appropriate form of "werden" followed by the infinitive form of the main verb. For example: **Beispiele** - Ich werde morgen ins Kino gehen. (I will go to the cinema tomorrow.) - Du wirst bald 18 Jahre alt sein. (You will soon be 18 years old.) - Er wird nächstes Jahr seinen Job wechseln. (He will change his job next year.) - Wir werden nächste Woche in den Urlaub fahren. (We will go on holiday next week.) - Ihr werdet heute Abend viel Spaß haben. (You will have a lot of fun tonight.) - Sie werden in Zukunft mehr Zeit für sich haben. (They will have more time for themselves in the future.) Note that the future tense can also be expressed using the present tense, especially in spoken German. For example, instead of saying "Ich werde morgen ins Kino gehen" you could also say "Ich gehe morgen ins Kino", which means the same thing. ## Zeitform III: Plusquamperfekt The Plusquamperfekt (Pluperfect) is a past tense in German that describes an action that had already happened before another action in the past. It is formed by using the auxiliary verb "haben" or "sein" in the Imperfekt (simple past) tense and adding the past participle of the main verb. The Plusquamperfekt is a past tense in German that describes an action that had already happened before another action in the past. It is formed by using the auxiliary verb **haben** or **sein** and adding the past participle of the main verb. The choice of auxiliary verb depends on the main verb. Verbs of **movement**, **change of state** or **reflexive verbs** usually use **sein**, while all other verbs use **haben**. The formation of the Plusquamperfekt is as follows: With the auxiliary verb **haben**: - Ich hatte gearbeitet. (I had worked.) - Du hattest gegessen. (You had eaten.) - Er hatte geschlafen. (He had slept.) - Wir hatten getanzt. (We had danced.) - Ihr hattet gelacht. (You had laughed.) - Sie hatten gesungen. (They had sung.) With the auxiliary verb **sein**: - Ich war gegangen. (I had gone.) - Du warst gekommen. (You had come.) - Er war gefallen. (He had fallen.) - Wir waren gelaufen. (We had run.) - Ihr wart geschwommen. (You had swum.) - Sie waren geflogen. (They had flown.) The Plusquamperfekt is often used in combination with the Perfekt tense to describe a sequence of past events. For example: - Du hattest gegessen, bevor du zum Bahnhof gegangen bist. (You had eaten before you went to the train station.)

The genitive case in German grammar is used to show possession, relationships between nouns, and to express certain types of actions. It is usually indicated by adding an "-s" or "-es" ending to the end of a noun or a noun phrase. The genitive is also used after certain prepositions and verbs, and can be used to replace possessive pronouns. While the genitive case is still used in modern German, it is not as common as it used to be and has been partially replaced by the dative case with prepositions.
ist sehr lang. (The tail of the dog is very long.)
ist sehr groß. (My friend's apartment is very large.)
verändert sich im Herbst. (The color of the leaves changes in autumn.)
bellt oft. (The neighbor's dog barks often.)
sind blau. (The child's eyes are blue.)
ist unbeschreiblich. (The beauty of nature is indescribable.)
berührt meine Seele. (The sound of the music touches my soul.)
liegt auf dem Tisch. (My brother's book is lying on the table.)
passen nicht zu ihrem Kleid. (The woman's shoes do not match her dress.)

Präteritum (also known as "simple past" or "preterite") is a grammatical tense in German that is used to describe actions or events that occurred in the past. It is commonly used in written texts, formal speech, and in some regions of Germany in spoken language.
The Präteritum tense is formed by conjugating the verb stem and adding specific endings depending on the subject. For example, the verb "sprechen" (to speak) in Präteritum is:

ich sprach (I spoke)
du sprachst (you spoke)
er/sie/es sprach (he/she/it spoke)
wir sprachen (we spoke)
ihr spracht (you all spoke)
sie sprachen (they spoke)

In spoken German, the Präteritum tense is often replaced by the Perfekt tense, which is formed with an auxiliary verb (usually "haben" or "sein") and the past participle of the main verb. The Perfekt tense is used in everyday conversation and is considered more colloquial than the Präteritum tense.
As they are often used in fairy tales (märchen) one of the best ways to study Präteritum is to read fairy tales.
Es war einmal eine kleine Maus, die in einem Wald
Eines Tages traf sie auf einen Löwen, der vor ihr
"Bitte fress mich nicht, Löwe. Ich bin so klein und würde dir kaum schmecken. Aber wenn du mich verschonst, verspreche ich dir, dass ich dir eines Tages helfen werde."
sie am Leben. Einige Zeit später wurde der Löwe in einem Netz gefangen und konnte sich nicht befreien. Die Maus
den Löwen in Not und begann, das Netz mit ihren scharfen Zähnen zu zerschneiden. So
Seitdem waren die Maus und der Löwe gute Freunde und halfen sich immer wieder gegenseitig.

Alternativ sentences could be written in 3 forms. | Satz I | Satz II | | :------------- | :------- | | Ich trinke keinen Tee. | Ich trinke Kaffee. | | Struktur | Formul | Beispiel | | :-- | :-- | :-- | | | Hauptsatz | anstatt, das s | Anstatt dass ich ins Kino gehe, bleibe ich zu Hause und lese ein Buch. | | Nebensatz | (an)statt, zu + inf | Anstatt zu joggen, gehe ich schwimmen. | | Infinitiv | stattessen + prä + G | Ich esse heute Abend nicht zu Hause. Ich werde stattessen mit Freunden in einem Restaurant essen. | **Beispiele** - Ich trinke keine Fanta. Ich trinke Cola. - Ich trinke statt der Fanta Cola. (Präp + G) - Anstatt, dass ich Fanta trinke, trinke ich Cola. (NS) - Anstatt Fanta zu trinken, trinke ich Cola. (Infinitive Satz) - Ich trinke keine Cola. Stattdessen trinke ich Fanta. (Adverb) (inversion) - Heißt das, dass man an der Uni Notizen lieber mit der Hand statt mit dem Laptop machen sollte? ## Kasus II: Genitiv The genitive case in German grammar is used to show possession, relationships between nouns, and to express certain types of actions. It is usually indicated by adding an "-s" or "-es" ending to the end of a noun or a noun phrase. The genitive is also used after certain prepositions and verbs, and can be used to replace possessive pronouns. While the genitive case is still used in modern German, it is not as common as it used to be and has been partially replaced by the dative case with prepositions. | | Masculine | Feminine | Neuter | Plural | | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | | Nominativ | der | die | das | die | | Akkusativ | den | die | das | die | | Dativ | dem | der | dem | den | | Genitiv | des | der | des | der | **Beispiele** 1. Das ist das Auto meines Vaters. (That is my father's car.) 2. Der Schwanz des Hundes ist sehr lang. (The tail of the dog is very long.) 3. Die Wohnung meiner Freundin ist sehr groß. (My friend's apartment is very large.) 4. Die Farbe der Blätter verändert sich im Herbst. (The color of the leaves changes in autumn.) 5. Der Hund des Nachbarn bellt oft. (The neighbor's dog barks often.) 6. Die Augen des Kindes sind blau. (The child's eyes are blue.) 7. Die Schönheit der Natur ist unbeschreiblich. (The beauty of nature is indescribable.) 8. Der Klang der Musik berührt meine Seele. (The sound of the music touches my soul.) 9. Das Buch meines Bruders liegt auf dem Tisch. (My brother's book is lying on the table.) 10. Die Schuhe der Frau passen nicht zu ihrem Kleid. (The woman's shoes do not match her dress.) ## Zeitform III: Praeteritum Präteritum (also known as "simple past" or "preterite") is a grammatical tense in German that is used to describe actions or events that occurred in the past. It is commonly used in written texts, formal speech, and in some regions of Germany in spoken language. The Präteritum tense is formed by conjugating the verb stem and adding specific endings depending on the subject. For example, the verb "sprechen" (to speak) in Präteritum is: ich sprach (I spoke) du sprachst (you spoke) er/sie/es sprach (he/she/it spoke) wir sprachen (we spoke) ihr spracht (you all spoke) sie sprachen (they spoke) In spoken German, the Präteritum tense is often replaced by the Perfekt tense, which is formed with an auxiliary verb (usually "haben" or "sein") and the past participle of the main verb. The Perfekt tense is used in everyday conversation and is considered more colloquial than the Präteritum tense. As they are often used in fairy tales (märchen) one of the best ways to study Präteritum is to read fairy tales. **Die Maus und der Löwe** Es war einmal eine kleine Maus, die in einem Wald lebte. Eines Tages traf sie auf einen Löwen, der vor ihr brüllte und sie zu fressen drohte. Die Maus aber sagte: "Bitte fress mich nicht, Löwe. Ich bin so klein und würde dir kaum schmecken. Aber wenn du mich verschonst, verspreche ich dir, dass ich dir eines Tages helfen werde." Der Löwe lachte über die Maus, aber ließ sie am Leben. Einige Zeit später wurde der Löwe in einem Netz gefangen und konnte sich nicht befreien. Die Maus hörte ihn brüllen und eilte herbei. Sie sah den Löwen in Not und begann, das Netz mit ihren scharfen Zähnen zu zerschneiden. So konnte der Löwe sich befreien und dankte der Maus für ihre Hilfe. Seitdem waren die Maus und der Löwe gute Freunde und halfen sich immer wieder gegenseitig.

children.value: "Passiversatzformen" in German refers to constructions that are used as alternatives to the typical passive voice structure. These are constructions that convey a passive-like meaning without using the standard "werden" (to be) + past participle combination. Instead, they often involve using reflexive pronouns or certain verbs.

In English, "Passiversatzformen" translates to "passive substitute forms" or "alternative passive constructions." These constructions are used when speakers want to express a passive idea but choose to do so in a different grammatical structure.
Man kann die Kopie nicht nur einfach lesen.
Die Kopie kann nur schwer gelesen werden.
Die Kopie ist nur schwer zu lesen.
Die Kopie lässt sich nur schwer lesen.
Das Kopie ist nur schwer lesbar.

Passive voice is a grammatical construction in which the subject of a sentence is the recipient of the action, rather than the performer of the action. In other words, in a passive sentence, the thing being acted upon is the grammatical subject of the sentence, while the agent (the entity that is performing the action) is often relegated to a prepositional phrase or omitted altogether.

For example, in the active sentence "John ate the pizza," "John" is the subject and the performer of the action, while "pizza" is the object and the thing being acted upon. In the passive version of this sentence, "The pizza was eaten by John," "pizza" becomes the subject, while "John" is introduced via a prepositional phrase.

Passive voice is often used when the speaker wants to emphasize the thing being acted upon or when the performer of the action is unknown, irrelevant, or intentionally being obscured. However, passive voice can sometimes make sentences more wordy and harder to understand, so it's important to use it judiciously.
In German language the passiv structure has those properties.
Use of the subject is not obligatory in passive sentence. However, it could be done in this way:

Accusative object in active sentence becomes subject in passive sentence.

werden + Partizip II + Inf. von werden

## Passiversatzformen "Passiversatzformen" in German refers to constructions that are used as alternatives to the typical passive voice structure. These are constructions that convey a passive-like meaning without using the standard "werden" (to be) + past participle combination. Instead, they often involve using reflexive pronouns or certain verbs. In English, "Passiversatzformen" translates to "passive substitute forms" or "alternative passive constructions." These constructions are used when speakers want to express a passive idea but choose to do so in a different grammatical structure. | Formulierung | Beispiel | Meaning (Bedeutung) | | :--------------- | :------------------- | :---- | | Aktiv + modalverb | Man kann die Kopie nicht nur einfach lesen. | können | | Passiv + modalverb | Die Kopie kann nur schwer gelesen werden. | können | | sein + zu + infinitiv | Die Kopie ist nur schwer zu lesen. | passiversatz (können / müssen / sollen) | | sich lassen + infinitiv | Die Kopie lässt sich nur schwer lesen. | passiversatz (können) | | adjektiv + suffix | Das Kopie ist nur schwer lesbar. | passiversatz (können) | ## Passivform Passive voice is a grammatical construction in which the subject of a sentence is the recipient of the action, rather than the performer of the action. In other words, in a passive sentence, the thing being acted upon is the grammatical subject of the sentence, while the agent (the entity that is performing the action) is often relegated to a prepositional phrase or omitted altogether. For example, in the active sentence "John ate the pizza," "John" is the subject and the performer of the action, while "pizza" is the object and the thing being acted upon. In the passive version of this sentence, "The pizza was eaten by John," "pizza" becomes the subject, while "John" is introduced via a prepositional phrase. Passive voice is often used when the speaker wants to emphasize the thing being acted upon or when the performer of the action is unknown, irrelevant, or intentionally being obscured. However, passive voice can sometimes make sentences more wordy and harder to understand, so it's important to use it judiciously. In German language the passiv structure has those properties. 1. Use of the subject is not obligatory in passive sentence. However, it could be done in this way: - Subjekt im A-Satz -> von + D im P-Satz 2. Accusative object in active sentence becomes subject in passive sentence. - Akk-Obj. im A-Satz -> Subjekt im P-Satz 3. In passiv sentence everytime we have always one more verb. - werden + Partizip II - sein + Partizip II + worden - werden + Partizip II + Inf. von werden Memorizing all time forms at the same time may result in confusion. The most often used forms of the Passive voice are `Präsens` and `Präteritum`. Therefore I recommend to learn the most common two forms first, and when you feel confortable with the use of these time forms. You can check the other ones. | Zeit | Tempus | Aktiv Beispiel | Passiv Beispiel | | :---------------: | :-----------------: | :-------------------------------: | :---------------------------------: | | die Gegenwart | das Präsens | Man liest das Buch. | Das Buch wird gelesen. | | die Vergangenheit | das Präteritum | Man las das Buch. | Das Buch wurde gelesen. | **Umformulierung** Ich fahre meine Mutter ins Krankenhaus. 1. Ich = Subjekt | meine Mutter = Akk. obj. 2. fahren (Präsens) -> (ist) gefahren 3. Fahren + Akk -> hat gefahren - Meine Mutter wird (von mir) ins Krankenhaus gefahren. | Zeit | Tempus | Aktiv Beispiel | Passiv Beispiel | | :---------------: | :-----------------: | :-------------------------------: | :---------------------------------: | | die Vergangenheit | das Perfekt | Man hat das Buch gelesen. | Das Buch ist gelesen worden. | | die Vergangenheit | das Plusquamperfekt | Man hatte das Buch gelesen. | Das Buch war gelesen worden. | | die Gelegenheit | das Futur I | Man wird das Buch lesen. | Das Buch wird gelesen werden. | | die Gelegenheit | das Futur II | Man wird das Buch gelesen haben. | Das Buch wird gelesen worden sein. | **Beispiele** - Katja Screibt einen Brief. (Präs. Aktiv.) - Ein Brief wird (von Katja) geschrieben. (Präs. Passiv.) - Katja schrieb einen Brief (Prät. Aktiv.) - Ein Brief wurde (von Katja) geschrieben. (Prät. Passiv.) - Katja hat einen Brief geschrieben. (Perf. Aktiv.) - Ein Brief ist (von Katja) geschrieben worden. (Perf. Passiv.) - Katja hatte einen Brief geschrieben. (Pqp. Aktiv.) - Ein Brief war geschrieben worden. (Pqp. Passiv.) - Katja wird einen Brief schrieben. (F1. Aktiv.) - Ein Brief wird geschrieben werden. (F1. Passiv.) - Katja wird einen Brief geschrieben haben. (F2. Aktiv.) (Disregard for now, usage is rarely) - Ein Brief von Katja geschrieben worden sein. (F2. Passiv.) - Laut einer Studie wurden seit Jahresbeginn in Deutschland und China deutlich mehr Autos verkauft. - An den deutschen Meeresküsten soll in Zukunft mehr Windkraft produziert werden. - Bis zum Jahr 2030 soll mit Windparks in der Nord- und Ostsee eine Kapazität von bis zu 20 Gigawatt Leistung realisiert werden. ## Satzstruktur IV: Modale Saetze Modal sentences provide information about how (wie?) / by which (wodurch) / in which way (auf welche Art / Weise) on a topic. **Beispiel:** **Dadurch** achten seine Ernährung und sich ausgewogen ernähren, kann mann fitter werden. **Through** paying attention to his diet and eating a balanced diet, man can become fitter. In this example Dadurch indicates the method, and statement answers the question **How** can one become fit? Modal sentences could be formed through three possibilities 1. Nebensatzkonnektor - indem | dadurch, dass - wie lernst du Vokabeln? - Ich lerne Vokabeln, indem ich sie ganz oft wiederhole. - wie lernst du Vokabeln? - Ich lerne Vokabeln dadurch, dass ich sie ganz oft wiederhole. - Man soll immer gesund essen. Man kann dadurch fitter Werden. - Ich habe ein Semester gesparrt, indem ich die Uni gewechselt habe. - Charles Lindbergh wurde berühmt, indem er 1927 über den Atlantik geflogen ist. - Dadurch, dass sich die Erde um sich selbst dreht, kommen Tag und Nacht zustande. - Indem ich früh aufstehe, habe ich genug Zeit für Sport. (By getting up early, I have enough time for sports.) 2. Verbindungsadverb - dadurch / so - Dadurch konnte ich meine Ziele erreichen. (This way, I was able to achieve my goals.) - So bin ich schneller ans Ziel gekommen. (This way, I reached my destination faster.) 2. Präpositionen - durch + Akk (= Methode) Nominalisierung - mit + Dat. (= Instrument) - Durch intensives Training hat er seine Sprachkenntnisse verbessert. (Through intensive training, he improved his language skills.) - Mit meinem Fahrrad fahre ich jeden Tag zur Arbeit. (I ride my bike to work every day.) ## Satzstruktur III: Final- und Adversativsatze # Finalsätze Finalsatz describes a goal or intention. Der Finalsatz gibt den Zweck, die Absicht oder das Ziel der beschriebenen Handlung oder des Sachverhalts an. Man trennt den Finalsatz durch ein Komma vom übergeordneten Satz ab. Finalsatz answers the question **wozu?** There is two common forms of creating final sentences. 1. **Infinitiv** : um .. zu .. 2. **Konnektor** : damit | | | |:--|:--| | **Handlung/Meinung/Status** | Wir brauchen einen Saugroboter. | **Zweck/Absicht** | Wir sparen Zeit. - **Nina:** Wozu brauchen wir einen Saugroboter? - **Sebastian:** Wir brauchen einen Saugroboter, **um** Zeit **zu** sparen. - **Sebastian:** Ich möchte einen Saugroboter kaufen, damit wir Zeit sparen. **Beispiele:** - Ich lerne Deutsch, **damit** ich mich auf Reisen verständigen kann. - Er spart Geld, **um** sich später ein Haus kaufen **zu** können. - Du drückst auf diesen Knopf, **um** die Maschine ein**zu**schalten. Der Finalsatz mit um … zu hat kein eigenes Subjekt. Deshalb ist diese Satzstruktur nur möglich, wenn das Subjekt im übergeordneten Satz und im Finalsatz gleich ist. The Finalsatz with um .. zu + (inf) structure only possible with the same subject. If the subject is changing then connector **damit** should be used. - Du machst kreisende Bewegungen, um jede Pore mit Chemie zu füllen. - Du füllst Teppichreiniger in die Maschine, damit ich den Teppich sauber machen kann. # Adversativsätze | Gegensätze Adversativsatz or Gegensatz indicates a opposite condition/situation to first sentence. Adversative Konjunktionen verwendet man, um eine Einschränkung, einen Widerspruch oder einen Gegensatz auszudrücken. Zwei Konjunktionen, die man oft benutzt, sind aber und doch. Some of the commonly used Adversativsatz connectors are: **aber, doch, jedoch** **Beispiele:** - Ich möchte eine eigene Praxis eröffnen, aber ich habe nicht genug Geld. - Ich möchte eine eigene Praxis eröffnen, doch ich habe nicht genug Geld. - Ich möchte eine eigene Praxis eröffnen, jedoch habe ich nicht genug Geld. Die Konjunktionen aber und doch stehen zwischen zwei Hauptsätzen. In beiden Hauptsätzen verändert sich die Reihenfolge der Satzteile nicht, wenn man die Sätze mit aber und doch verbindet. Deshalb sagt man, dass aber auf Position 0 steht. | Satz I | Satz II | | :-- | :-- | | Ich bin kein reicher Mann. | Ich kann viel arbeiten. - Ich bin kein reicher Mann, **aber** ich kann viel arbeiten. - Ich bin kein reicher Mann, kann **aber** viel arbeiten. - Ich bin kein reicher Mann, **jedoch** kann ich viel arbeiten. - Ich bin kein reicher Mann. Ich kann **jedoch** viel arbeiten. - Ich bin kein reicher Mann, kann **jedoch** viel arbeiten.

Mit anstatt dass nicht nur das. - wegen dir -> denetwegen - wegen mir -> meinetwegen - wir müssen immer erst der Subjekt nennnen. --- 3. Textproduktion - überfliegen = skimming - text - Einleitung - welcher Text, welcher Autor, welches Thema? - Ihre These: Wie ist Ihre Meinung zum Thema? - Hauptteil - Argumente: Gründe für Ihre Meinung - Schluss - Lösung für Problem vorschlagen - Fazit: Stellungnahme kurz zusammenfassen - Zitat | reported speech | sei --- Minor Topics --- Composita - der Lerntipp, s - der Lernpartner, = - die Lernpartnerin, die Lernpartnerinnen - der Lerntyp, die Lerntypen - der Stil, die Lernstile - die Lernerfahrung, die Lernerfahrungen ---- Abkürzung --- Das Verb "werden" Werden in deutschen Sprache hat 3 funktionen - Werden als hilfsverb: benutzen wir mit Passiv - Passiv: Etwas wird gemacht. (werden + P II) - Futur I: Etwas wird passieren. (Werden + Inf.) - Werden als Vollverb (mit Bedeutung) - Morgen werde ich 32. (I become 32 tomorrow) (werden als einziges Verb im Satz mit Bedeutung.) - Wenn ich unwohl fühle, werde ich unruhig. - sein, haben, werden + verb = Zeit/Modus - ich habe ein neues Auto gekauft. -> perf. aktiv. - Ein Auto wird gekauft. -> Präs passiv. - both are gekauft -> Partizip II but the time is different. -- Nicht Kategorisiert - grammatik - Wann zu wervenden? "zu + infinitiv" - wenn ende mit adjektiv - ex. ich habe lust, etwas zu tun. - ex. es ist gut, etwas praktisch anzuwenden. - in und wo? immer dativ - fast alle verben geht akkusativ automatisch akkusativ objekt - kasus hangt mit präposition oder verb - präpositionen auswendig lernen - verben + präposition - warten auf - redemittel aus der lektionen - plural - das Taxi, die Taxen - der Kaktus, die Kakteen - der Lehrer, = - der Fahrer, = (endet mit er) - partizip I, partizip II - dadurch, dass, indem | gleiche bedeutung -> antworten die frage `wie?` - wie lernst du Vokabeln? - Ich lerne Vokabeln, indem ich sie ganz oft wiederhole. - wie lernst du Vokabeln? - Ich lerne Vokaebeln dadurch, dass ich sie ganz oft wiederhole. - Warum lernst du Deutsch? - Ich lerne Deutsch, weil ich in Deutschland studiere. - Wozu lernst du Deutsch? Ich lerne Deutsch, um in Deutschland zu studieren. - präpositionen steht immer vor der Nomen | präpositionen artikel nomen - der Gedanke, die Gedanken - denken an + A. - gedanken + G. - Modus | Modus bedeutet ein Zustand - 3 Modi in Deutschensprache - Modus des Verbs - Modus des Aktiv und Passiv - Aktiv nutzen wir, wenn: - handelnde Person ist bekannt, - handelnde Person wichtig ist. - Person im Focus - Beispiele - Der Arzt operiert den Patienten. (3.Ps, Aktiv, Präs) - Mama hat eine Tomatensuppe gekocht. (3.Ps, Aktiv, Perfekt) - Passiv nutzen wir, wenn: - handelnde Person ist unbekannt, - handelnde Person ist unwichtig, - Handlung im Focus - Subjekt ungleich handelnde Person. - Der Patient wird operiert. (3.Ps. Passiv. Präsens) - Eine Tomatensuppe ist gekocht worden. (3.Ps. Passiv. Perfekt) - adjektiv endungen - deutsch - isch -> deutsche endung - optimistisch - lich - herrlich, freundlich - ig - fertig, geistig, regelmaßig - lateinisch, international - -iv, -al international ending - aussagen - zustimmen - ich stimme mit dir zu | trennbar mit person is dativ. - zustimmen + D = wiedersprechen + D | wiedersprechen ist nicht trennbar - wörter - anwenden - verwenden both means to use anwenden ist für abstrakt - w: auf dem Computer tippt man

In German, a "Relativsatz" is a relative clause. Relative clauses provide additional information about a noun in the main clause and are introduced by relative pronouns such as "der," "die," "das," "welcher," "welche," "welches," etc. These pronouns are used to refer back to a noun in the main clause, connecting the two clauses.
Here's a simple example in English:
Main clause: The book is interesting.
that I bought yesterday is interesting.

In this example, "das ich gestern gekauft habe" (that I bought yesterday) is the relative clause, providing additional information about the noun "Buch" (book) in the main clause. The relative pronoun "das" is used to connect the two clauses.

This table shows the declension of relative pronouns based on gender and case. Note that the plural form for the dative and genitive cases is the same: "denen" for dative and "deren" for genitive. The relative pronouns in the genitive case (dessen and deren) indicate possession or association.

## Partizip I und II als Adjektiv

_data.text:
## Irreale Bedingungssätze mit dem Konjunktiv II This group of sentences are there to describe hypothetical, irreal, wishful, speculative or forecasting conditions. In Grammar they are used with Partizip II verb form. There is two forms of Konjunktiv II sentences: **1. Konjunktiv II im Präteritum:** - Describes a conditional hypothetical alternative that is binded to a condition not happened in the past. - Conjugation follows **präteritum + umlaut** formula - fanden/fänden, gingen/gingen, kamen/kämen | | | |:--|:--| | Real | **Wenn** ich Zeit **hatte**, **bin** ich gerne **gereist**. | Irreal | **Wenn** ich Zeit **hätte**, **wäre** ich gerne **gereist**. **2. Konkjunktiv II im Präsens:** - Describes hypothetical, speculative, wishful or forecasting statement about the future. - Partizip II conjugation follows **würden + Infinitiv** formula. | | | |:--|:--| | Real | **Wenn** ich Zeit habe, **reise** ich gerne. | Irreal | **Wenn** ich Zeit **hätte**, **würde** ich gerne **reisen**. # Conjugations | | sein | haben | können | dürfen | müssen | wollen | sollen | werden | |:-- |:-- |:-- |:-- |:-- |:-- |:-- |:-- |:-- | | ich | wäre | hätte | könnte | dürfte | müsste | wollte | sollte | würde | du | wär(e)st | hättest | könntest | dürftest | müsstest | wolltest | solltest | würdest | er, sie, es | wäre | hätte | könnte | dürfte | müsste | wollte | sollte | würde | wir | wären | hätten | könnten | dürften | müssten | wollten | sollten | würden | ihr | wär(e)t | hättet | könntet | dürftet | müsstet | wolltet | solltet | würdet | sie | wären | hätten | könnten | dürften | müssten | wolletn | sollten | würden ## Indirekte Rede Indirect or reported speech is grammatical mechanism of reporting without directly quoting. It is often used in newspapers. **direkte Rede** Fabian sagt: "*Ich* gehe jetzt nach Hause." (I am going home now.) **indirekte Rede** Er sagte, *er* **gehe** jetzt nach Hause. On the reformulation (umformulierung) of the sentence 4 things needs to be noticed of change. 1. Pronomen: 1. Person -> 3. Person 2. Verbform: Indikativ -> Konjunktiv I or II 3. Ortsangaben: ex. hier -> dort 4. Zeitangaben: heute -> an diesem Tag, gestern -> am Tag **Conjugation of Konjunktiv I** | Pronomen | Konjunktiv I | | :-- | :-- | | ich | sei | du | sei(e)st | er/sie/es | sei | wir | seien | ihr | seiet | sie | seien In 2. Person (du/ihr) Konjunktiv I is very rarely used therefore omitted in this section. In 3. Person singular for other words, only thing needs to be done is remove "n" from **Infinitiv** form. - leben -> er lebe - haben -> sie habe In 1. person singular (ich), 1. person plural (wir), and 3. person plural (sie), Konjunktiv II is used instead of Konjunktiv I - Er sagt, sie **würden** ins Kino gehen. (Konjunktiv II) - Er sagt, sie **gehen** ins Kino. (Indikativ) - Menschen mit Herz- und Lungenerkrankungen seien besonders gefährdet. The difference between **Indikativ** and **Konjunktiv II**. The first one proposes a factual knowledge, while secondary expresses what is heard. source: https://studyflix.de/deutsch/indirekte-rede-3619 source: https://easy-deutsch.de/verben/konjunktiv-1/ ## Modalverben für Vermutungen und Geruechte Subjektive verwendung der Modalverben. Modal verbs other than their regular usage, could be used to express assertations and wishes. This type of usage often revealed from the context. **Vermutungen mit müssen, dürfen und können** | 100% | 90% | 75% | 50% | |:-- |:-- |:-- |:-- | | sehr sicher | fast sicher | wahrscheinlich | möglich | | muss | müsste | dürfte | könnte | source: https://www.hueber.de/media/36/SiAuB_C1_1_Grammatikuebersicht.pdf Access (25-Apr-2023) ## Relativsatz In German, a "Relativsatz" is a relative clause. Relative clauses provide additional information about a noun in the main clause and are introduced by relative pronouns such as "der," "die," "das," "welcher," "welche," "welches," etc. These pronouns are used to refer back to a noun in the main clause, connecting the two clauses. __Here's a simple example in English:__ Main clause: The book is interesting. Relative clause: The book that I bought yesterday is interesting. __In German:__ Hauptsatz: Das Buch ist interessant. Relativsatz: __Das__ Buch, __das__ ich gestern gekauft habe, ist interessant. In this example, "das ich gestern gekauft habe" (that I bought yesterday) is the relative clause, providing additional information about the noun "Buch" (book) in the main clause. The relative pronoun "das" is used to connect the two clauses. It's important to match the __gender__, __number__, and __case__ of the relative pronoun with the noun it refers to in the main clause. The choice of the relative pronoun depends on the gender and case of the noun, as well as whether the noun is a person or a thing. | Case | Masculine | Feminine | Neuter | Plural | |:----------------|:---------------------|:---------------------|:---------------------|:---------------------| | Nominative | der | die | das | die | | Accusative | den | die | das | die | | Dative | dem | der | dem | denen | | Genitive | dessen | deren | dessen | deren | This table shows the declension of relative pronouns based on gender and case. Note that the plural form for the dative and genitive cases is the same: "denen" for dative and "deren" for genitive. The relative pronouns in the genitive case (dessen and deren) indicate possession or association. | Main Clause | Relative Clause | Relative Pronoun | Case | Question | |:---------------------|:-------------------------------------------------|:------------------|:----------|:---------------| | Der Mann | ... der mir geholfen hat. | der | Nominative | Wer? (Who?) | | Die Frau | ... die ich gestern getroffen habe. | die | Nominative | Wer? (Who?) | | Das Buch | ... das ich gerade lese. | das | Nominative | Was? (What?) | | Main Clause | Relative Clause | Relative Pronoun | Case | Question | |:---------------------|:-------------------------------------------------|:------------------|:----------|:---------------| | Der Freund | ... den ich gestern besucht habe. | den | Accusative | Wen? (Whom?) | | Die Stadt | ... die ich letzten Sommer besucht habe. | die | Accusative | Wen? (Whom?) | | Das Auto | ... das ich mir gestern gekauft habe. | das | Accusative | Was? (What?) | | Main Clause | Relative Clause | Relative Pronoun | Case | Question | |:---------------------|:-------------------------------------------------|:------------------|:----------|:--------------------| | Der Mann | ... dem ich das Buch gegeben habe. | dem | Dative | Wem? | | Die Frau | ... der ich gestern geholfen habe. | der | Dative | Wem? | | Das Geschenk | ... das ich meiner Freundin gegeben habe. | das | Dative | Wem? | | Die Frau | ... mit denen ich gestern gesprochen habe. | denen | Dative | Mit wem? | | Der Hund | ... mit denen ich oft spiele. | denen | Dative | Mit wem? | | Das Haus | ... in dem wir letztes Jahr gewohnt haben. | dem | Dative | In wem? | | Main Clause | Relative Clause | Relative Pronoun | Case | Question | |:---------------------|:-------------------------------------------------|:------------------|:----------|:----------------------| | Der Vater | ... dessen Auto gestohlen wurde. | dessen | Genitive | Wessen? (Whose?) | | Die Frau | ... deren Hund krank ist. | deren | Genitive | Wessen? (Whose?) | | Das Buch | ... dessen Autor ich bewundere. | dessen | Genitive | Wessen? (Whose?) | | Der Freund | ... dessen Geburtstag wir feiern. | dessen | Genitive | Wessen? (Whose?) | | Die Stadt | ... deren Einwohner sich freuen. | deren | Genitive | Wessen? (Whose?) |
